newsitem.title: USA: Geraldine Ferraro weighing U.S. Senate run.
newsitem.headline: Geraldine Ferraro weighing U.S. Senate run.

text.p: Former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro said Tuesday she was giving serious consideration to challenging Republican Sen. Alfonse D'Amato for his job.
Ferraro, 61, said in an interview that she wants to finish writing a book and then consult with various political and labour leaders before making a decision by December.

The former Democratic congresswoman from the New York borough of Queens rose to national political prominence as the first woman to run for vice president on a major party ticket. She was presidential hopeful Walter Mondale's running mate in 1984.
She lost a bid for the Democratic nomination to run against D'Amato in 1992. Most recently, she has been a political commentator on CNN's political show "Crossfire."
Asked why she would return to public life, Ferraro cited an inscription on a coffee mug she recently was given.

"It has a picture of the Capitol, and it says 'Democracy is not a spectator sport,' and it really isn't," she said. "I'm good at legislating, at getting things done. If I were to do anything, that would be it."
Ferraro has been weighing a challenge to D'Amato for several months. In February she sent letters to potential supporters asking them to delay making a decision on whom to endorse to run against him.

The question of her candidacy was raised again publicly in an interview published Tuesday in the New York Times, in which she was quoted as saying, "If it were today, I'd probably say, 'Yeah, I'm going to go.'"
Ferraro said she thought D'Amato, after an 18-year stint in the Senate, was beatable, given his votes on such issues as the environment, education and the budget.
A public opinion poll in March showed Ferraro leading D'Amato 47 percent to 43 percent.
D'Amato last year was active in pursuing the Whitewater investigation against the Clintons and was a heavy supporter of former Sen. Bob Dole's unsuccessful Republican presidential campaign.
Two New York Democrats have already declared their interest in the Senate race -- Representative Charles Schumer of Brooklyn and New York City's Public Advocate Mark Green.
